Posts.Content: ktl7 wrote: My pathology report post surgery indicates a high grade DCIS with focal comedo necrosis. It also states that the pattern is cribriform. From what I have read, cribriform is a pattern associated with low grade cancer. Would anyone have some insight regarding this matter? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Pathology Report Post Surgery ktl7 mnmbeck

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2013 09:35AM ktl7 wrote: Dear Blessing2011 and Bessie, Thank you for your responses, your input makes perfect sense. I was thinking the two findings completely conflicted with one another, but it makes sense that you could have several different things going on in one tumor. Thank you! I was diagnosed in October with DCIS non-invasive, intermediate grade, necrosis, ER/PR POS. Post surgery path report indicates high grade, but the surgeon never mentioned that to me when I saw him at the 1-week follow-up appointment post surgery. I just happened to notice that tidbit when I was going over my report this past weekend. It kind of startled me. I am assuming it is still considered non-invasive, but I am starting to wonder if he left any other important particulars out of our discussion. I should have been better prepared to ask him more questions. I just had my surgery at the end of October. My surgeon was very good about explaining the DCIS diagnosis and my options for surgery, but he didn't go over my biopsy pathology report with a fine-tooth comb. He highlighted the portions that were pertinent to what his approach would be (and my options) for surgery, such as the grade and the benefits/potential side effects of performing a sentinel node dissection. The surgeon really didn't discuss too many of the details contained in my post surgery path report, however, I was provided a copy. He did explain the "highlights" of the report, i.e., the nodes tested negative (2) and the margins were clear. I was referred to a medical pathologist, who I will see tomorrow. I certainly like the idea of a nurse navigator. I have tried to read as much as possible, but sometimes I think I am doing myself a disservice because there are so many variable involved. This is the first time that I have ever joined an online discussion and I am so pleased that I did. Thanks again for your help and your perspective. I hope that you are both doing well at this stage of your recovery. With much appreciation, ktl7
